nodes.text: The degree of incumbency advantage in political institutions determines whether good or bad governments are selected and whether regimes adapt to environmental change; specifically, perfect democracy selects the most competent government, deviations can allow persistent bad governments, and greater democracy improves adaptability under stochastic shocks

Method: dynamic discrete-time model of government formation where governments are feasible coalitions, each coalition has competence u_G, individuals get utility from government competence and rents from holding office, and changes require both societal votes and consent of l current members; equilibrium characterized by a transition mapping phi
Claim: In a perfect democracy (no incumbency advantage, l = 0) the most competent government always emerges and is the unique stable government
Claim: Any deviation from perfect democracy (l > 0) allows at least one other stable government besides the best, and under some configurations even the least competent government can persist forever

Evidence / Example: For n=6, k=3, l=1 (one incumbent consent needed) if initial government is {4,5,6} the dynamics make all improvements unstable and none of its members will consent, so the worst government {4,5,6} persists forever

Claim / Result (nonstochastic): Beyond perfect democracy there is no universal ordering among imperfect democracies and dictatorships; depending on parameters and initial government, less democratic regimes can sometimes lead to better long-run governments

Claim / Result (stochastic): When environmental shocks change government competences and shocks are infrequent, greater democracy (lower l) increases the probability that high-competence or the best government will come to power â€” democracy confers greater institutional flexibility

Claim / Result: In stochastic environments royalty-like dictatorships (where particular individuals are irreplaceable) can outperform junta-like dictatorships because guaranteed incumbency for specific members can reduce blocking due to fear of further changes

Claim / Method result: Political equilibria can be characterized by a recursive single-valued mapping phi (mapping each government to a stable target or itself); for sufficiently high discount factors phi is the unique acyclic political equilibrium and equivalently generates acyclic Markov perfect equilibria in an explicit proposal/vote game

Result (Proposition 1): Properties of stable governments: (1) two distinct stable governments can share at most l-1 members; (2) if l=0 then only the best government is stable; (3) if l>=1 there are at least two stable governments and the worst may be stable; (4) if l=k (unanimity) then every feasible government is stable

Result (Proposition 2 and Assumption on abilities): For large n and competence additive in member abilities, there exist stable governments that exclude all top-percentile individuals; more generally one can construct stable governments that avoid any prespecified small set of individuals, implying persistence of low-ability governments even as n grows

Claim / Synthesis: In nonstochastic settings, imperfect democracy often yields multiple basins of attraction and can lock in low-quality governments; the equilibrium outcome depends strongly on initial government identity and institutional parameters (m,k,l)

Conclusion: The main advantage of democratic regimes may be institutional flexibility and adaptability to shocks rather than superior performance under fixed conditions; democracies are more likely to attain best governments after shocks, while dictatorships may resist beneficial change

Assumption: Analysis assumes perfect common information about competences, stage payoffs with rents for office (so members always prefer being in government), finite feasible-coalition set, and voting/consent thresholds parameterized by l and m

Limitation: The stochastic equilibrium characterization relies on shocks being sufficiently infrequent and on high discount factors; frequent shocks or richer informational frictions (unobserved abilities) complicate existence and structure of equilibria and are left for future work
